bibl.title: Letter from William H. Welch to Howard A. Kelly, November 1,[19--]

div1.p: Welch writes about the mosquito theory of yellow fever transmission and the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from William H. Welch to Howard A. Kelly, November 1, [19--]
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
HOWARD A. KELLY, M. D.
LIBRARY
1406 EUTAW PLACE, BALTIMORE, MD.
CABLE ADDRESS, “HAKELY,” BALTIMORE
Nov. 1,
Dear Kelly-
div1.p:
I am shocked to run across the en-
closed unanswered letter, but, as, you
know, I have survived many similar
shocks, although I wonder that I have a
friendly correspondent left-

My remembrance of the circumstances
is this- The yellow Fever commission
had already started certain lines of work,
particularly on the Sanarelli bacillus, in
which Sternberg was then especially inter-
ested.

The question of testing Finlay's mosquito
hypothesis was discussed, and after con-
sultation with Sternberg and I think also
with myself by Reed it was decided to start
work on this line. No member of the Com-
mission had much confidence in the theory
as Finlay's own experiments seemed to afford
AC
Dc
no support, Sternberg himself was especially skep-
tical. Before the experiments were actually
under way, but after the general plan had
been agreed upon, Lazear, who had change
of the Clinical studies, and was, I have
been told, quite skeptical about the mosqui-
to theory, was making the rounds one day in
the yellow fever word, when a mosquito
lighted on his hand or arm. Instead of
working it off, he said 'This is a chance to
test the mosquito theory', and let the mos-
quito remain and bite him. At about
the right time after this bite he came down
with yellow fever.

Of course this was not really an experi-
ment under controlled conditions, and no
conclusion could be drawn from it. I do
not see how Lazear himself could have
regarded it as an experiment of any value.
I question whether Lazear took the matter
at the time very seriously- It was
after this that the classical experi-
ments were started, but not long after
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
807 SAINT PAUL STREET
BALTIMORE, MARYLAND
Whether the mosquito was identified
at the time as stegomyia by Lazear I
do not know, but there would be every
presumption that it was stegomyia,

Whether you would care to present the
case just as I have stated it, I should
question. Lazear really was a martyr
to the cause, and it is not necessary
to destroy this view by going into
every detail.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, William H. Welch. Did you see Curling's five tribute
to Halsted in the last number of
'Science'?
